body: I can do that, I am just not that used to it.

Why pass input validation errors to the `callback` instead of throwing them ?

Normally when these are missing it would have just thrown.
I think you meant bad practice and right you are. I was thinking about that for the `fs.exists` but missed this one =/
Generally calling the callback synchronously is considered bad practice. Would be nice to wrap in `process.nextTick`
If you create the error objects synchronously then the call stack is going to be a lot nicer. Creating error objects in another tick of the event loop makes for a bad stack trace
Eh, already landed it =(

I think we should be fine. People should only be running this in test suites so they will be able to debug the missing option a lot more. Although, if a PR comes in about this I prob wouldn't stop it.
We were intentionally keeping the regexp sniffing digits to keep it as efficient as possible. Please move back to the previous version.
Can we put the `parseFloat` on the previous line? It feels weird to combine comparison and type coercion =/
Also, we will need to fallback `options.threshold` to `0`.

Oh, and we need to specify the radix for `parseFloat` to avoid parsing it as an octal.

``` js
parseFloat(totalDifference, 10);
```
We should be renaming this variable since it's now the percentage difference, not the total difference.
To keep the API as simple as possible for future changes, please don't send back the `diffPath`. The user already knows what the is since they gave it to us.

I remember why I changed this - in case of only a few pixel difference, we get a result like this from compare.exe:
  Channel distortion: RMSE
    red: 0.00129297 (5.07046e-006)
    green: 0 (0)
    blue: 0.00158356 (6.21002e-006)
    all: 0.00118031 (4.62868e-006)
So, we can either use (. \* ) or /\d+.?\d \* (e-\d+)?/ to allow for something small

Ah, interesting. We should probably isolate the parser to a separate function so we can test these individually. I imagine it will become very tedious to create a set of separate images for each of these cases.

As for the regexp, being explicit is always more useful than being implicit. Additionally, we should probably include examples of the different values in comments. The regexp should look like:

``` js
/all: (\d+\.?\d*) \((\d+\.?\d*e?\-?\d*)\)/)
```

This allows for `0`, `0.1`, `0.1e-3`, and even unexpected cases like `1e3`, `1.0e3`.

There is a lot going on in this line.
- Using `typeof` to detect undefined is only necessary when looking at a global (e.g. `typeof window === 'undefined')
  - Otherwise, we can use a simpler direct comparison with `undefined` (e.g. `options.foo === undefined`)
- We don't need to detect `undefined`, a fallback will work fine (e.g. `var foo = options.bar || baz;`)
- We don't need to be defensive and coerce `options.threshold`. We can assume the developer wants the library to work and will pass in a `Number` (i.e. no `isNaN/parseFloat` necessary)
- In JS, all `Numbers` are 64 bit floats. The decimal isn't necessary; `0` will work fine.
  - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Number

The simplified result should be:

``` js
var threshold = options.threshold || 0;
```
Can you move back this line? It is noise in the PR =/
`different` is very ambiguous. Can we name the file `threshold-under` so it is semantic to the test?

This doesn't read that well. Can we update it to:

``` js
comparing different images under a threshold
```
Ah, I think I confused these 2 text cases. Ignore this comment =/

body:
Can we update the comment in the previous line to include the `E/e` format?

```
// Attempt to find variant between 'all: 0 (0)' or 'all: 40131.8 (0.612372)'
```
This regexp grew a lot in complexity. Why are we moving to `?:` for some of the groups?
Ah, I see. We are trying to be more accurate with the matches.
For extra safety, I am going to copy over the `Ee-` logic to the first half as well.

We are going to want an instance bound `gm` to prevent sharing a common `gm` instance across different image diffs (e.g. someone might want to run both GraphicsMagick and ImageMagick diffs in the same script)
We should now be using `this.gm` instead of `gm` since we create it via the constructor

As a heads up, we don't need `typeof` to prevent `undefined` errors unless we are checking a global value

```
// Will throw when `window` isn't defined (e.g. in Node.js)
window === 'undefined'

// Won't throw
typeof window === 'undefined'
window.x === undefined
```

Why not more readable error messages? These parameters are read in using input from the user (eventually) so there's a chance the consuming code could have erroneous input. An assert doesn't really explain the issue all that well.

These assertions are for preventing typos from developers. There's not really a case where the error would come from user error:
- If the file doesn't exist, then we will get an `ENOENT` error during the earlier `fs.stat`/`fs.exists` call and we won't be upscaling the image
  - https://github.com/uber/image-diff/blob/1.3.0/lib/image-diff.js#L122-L128
  - https://github.com/uber/image-diff/blob/1.3.0/lib/image-diff.js#L132
  - https://github.com/uber/image-diff/blob/1.3.0/lib/image-diff.js#L33-L52
  - https://github.com/uber/image-diff/blob/1.3.0/lib/image-diff.js#L137
  - https://github.com/uber/image-diff/blob/1.3.0/lib/image-diff.js#L170-L173
- Otherwise, we will always be receiving `height`/`width` from `gm.size` so if those don't exist, then we have a deeper problem in `gm` itself
Isn't NorthWest the default value, so we may not have to set it explicitly?

Yea, it's the default but I prefer to be explicit and we could parameterize it easily. For example, in the following images, what if someone wanted the smaller one to move to the lower right when upscaled?

https://github.com/uber/image-diff/blob/1.3.0/test/test-files/checkerboard.png

https://github.com/uber/image-diff/blob/1.3.0/test/test-files/checkerboard-excess.png

Note: Currently for gravity, it will make the 2 images look the same except there will be a transparent edge for the smaller one
:+1: gotcha
Cool!

body: I'm inclined to say this PR will hurt more than help: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10376206/what-is-the-preferred-bash-shebang

diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
-#!/usr/bin/env bash
+#!/bin/sh
body:
@twolfson @dawsonbotsford

One is guarantied that `/bin/sh` is on all systems. And since the code is POSIX compatible - and the file is named release._sh_ - then there is no need to load `bash` as a faster / more lightweight shell like `dash` could be symlinked from `/bin/sh`. [Also note that FreeBSD doesn't ship with `bash` by default](https://www.freebsd.org/doc/en/articles/linux-users/shells.html)

The discussion linked above is concerned about whether or not to use `/usr/bin/env sh` or simply `/bin/sh` which makes sense when talking about `bash` as a user wish to use a newer version of said. But whom are not allowed to change `/bin`.

But since - as stated before - this code is POSIX compatible the discussion is not as relevant. One could however still argue that they have symlinked `/usr/bin/env sh` to `dash` but the system's version is `bash` in which case the performance boost will be lost. But using `/usr/bin/env` one extra process needs to be started which also cost something.

Anyway, the main idea behind changing the shebang was that a `.sh` file should be POSIX compatible and if a shebang is present it should be for the `sh` executable. I think you can compare it to saving a png file with the `.jpg` suffix. One could also rename the file to `release.bash` or `release`.
